awd_titl_txt: The Microphysics of Plate Boundary Formation: Dynamic Recrystallization and Phase Mixing
awd_abstract_narration:
The modern theory of plate tectonics explains much about the structure and workings of our planet from sea-floor spreading to subduction and mountain building. Although this powerful theory tells us so much about activity on the surface of our planet, relatively little is known about how plate tectonics starts and the underlying physics that allows it to continue over time. There is little doubt that convection of the mantle drives the motion of these plates.  However, the details of how this process occurs and how it originated are far from complete. Plate tectonics is defined by special boundaries, namely subduction zones, ridges, and strike-slip fault margins at the edges of continents.  These boundaries are formed at the top of the mantle, which requires some special physical properties that localize deformation through certain mechanisms. Thankfully, the Earth has provided an important clue through the abundance of rocks called mylonites that are found at plate boundaries. These fine-grain rocks provide evidence of the physics that might tell us how plate tectonics started and how it persists today. The investigator's research captures the essential physics of the mechanisms that lead to development of mylonites that persist as weak zones and ultimately develop as plate boundaries. This work is the primary focus of the doctoral dissertation project of a graduate student in the PI's lab and will help develop the student's skills as a scientist in addition to providing fundamental research necessary for the future progress of our understanding of the generation of tectonic plates. The experimental techniques developed in this research will be applied to new undergraduate lab exercises that demonstrate complex processes involving feedback between microstructural development and mechanical properties of the material. 

The Earth is unique in the solar system in that it displays plate tectonics. The physical explanation for this behavior remains a major challenge.  This research focuses on the influence of (i) a secondary solid phase and (ii) localized deformation on lithospheric strength with implications for plate tectonics. The project emphasizes a transformative approach to laboratory experiments designed to investigate the role of a second phase in the deformation of olivine, the primary phase in Earth's upper mantle. To achieve steady-state microstructures and thus steady state creep rates, the team will fabricate two-phase samples with grain sizes significantly larger than the steady-state grain size. They will then deform these samples in torsion to large shear strains, such that dynamic recrystallization produces a steady-state grain size.  The dependence of strain rate on stress is determined through rate or load steps. Some samples will be annealed after large strain to measure grain growth in thoroughly mixed, dynamically recrystallized samples. Grain-size reduction due to dynamic recrystallization of coarse-grained rocks is well established both experimentally and in observations of natural shear zones. This process leads to a grain-size sensitive process and associated strain weakening. However, without continued deformation and dynamic recrystallization, grains will grow and ultimately lead to hardening that makes reactivation of a shear zone difficult. In polyphase materials, pinning of grain boundaries by a secondary phase inhibits grain growth, allowing localization to persist or to be more easily reactivated. For this process to be effective, the phases must be thoroughly mixed. Understanding both the chemical and mechanical processes that lead to phase mixing and localization is the primary goal of this proposal.

por.por_cntn:
To study the mechanical and microstructural evolution of polymineralic rocks, we performed deformation experiments on a two-phase system consisting of olivine + ferropericlase. Our two-phase system was used as an analog for two-phase systems typically found on Earth, such as olivine + orthopyroxene. In this study, we characterized our two-phase system across a range of secondary-phase fractions from 10 to 80 vol% ferropericlase, as well as both of the single-phase end members. Each sample was deformed in torsion at T = 1523 K, P = 300 MPa at a constant strain rate up to a final shear strain of γ = 6 to 7. Measured values of the stress exponent, n, indicate that olivine in our samples deformed by a dislocation accommodated grain boundary sliding mechanism while ferropericlase deformed via dislocation creep. From the stress versus strain data at  γ <1 we observed that in samples containing <50 vol% ferropericlase, the olivine controls the observed macroscopic deformation as a load bearing framework, while in samples with >50% ferropericlase, ferropericlase controls the macroscopic deformation as an interconnected weak layer. At high strains, however, the measured stresses are larger than predicted by a simple rule of mixtures, and greater than the measured stress for either single-phase end member.

Microstructurally, grain size approximately doubled in our single-phase experiments for both mineral types, while grain size of both phases remained the same or decreased during the two-phase experiments. This demonstrated the efficacy of interphase boundaries to pin grains of both phases, hindering their ability to grow and migrate during deformation. Measurements of the crystallographic preferred orientation (CPO) calculated from electron backscatter diffraction (EBSD) patterns indicated that the strength of the CPO is significantly weakened by any amount of secondary phase added. We interpret this as interphase boundary pinning also keeping grains from rotating into favorable orientations for slip to occur. Rather than grain size being predicted by the stress, as is the case in single-phase materials, a Zener relationship was fit to grain size measurements in our two-phase samples. This indicates that grain size of the primary phase is controlled by the grain size and amount of the secondary phase present, as well as how the secondary phase is distributed throughout the primary phase matrix. In samples containing <50 vol% ferropericlase, the ferropericlase is distributed at triple junctions in the olivine matrix, while in samples containing >50 vol% ferropericlase, the olivine is distributed along grain boundaries in the ferropericlase matrix.

One remaining question in studying polymineralic rocks lies in determining the dominant microphysical mechanisms by which two mineral phases mix with another, such that the proportion of interphase boundaries increases relative to grain boundaries. If mineral phases are initially distributed in separate domains from one another, understanding how they mix is important so that phase boundary pinning processes can effectively occur. In an attempt to address this issue, we synthesized two-phase materials in which each phase initially exists in large separate domains from one another. Sample types included large single crystal inclusions in a polycrystalline matrix and samples with monomineralic layers stacked on top of one another. These samples were deformed in torsion in a high-resolution gas-medium deformation apparatus at T = 1523 K, P = 300 MPa and a constant strain rate up to a final shear strain of γ = 4 to 20 and compared to our observations in well-mixed starting materials from our previous studies.

Microstructural observations from these samples indicate that mixing via a mechanical mechanism is difficult. For example, in samples with a single crystal inclusion of MgO in a polycrystalline olivine matrix, very little mixing is observed at the boundary between the two phases, and any mixing that is observed only occurs at the ends of the single crystal inclusion where stress is concentrated. Instead, an additional chemical mechanism, the addition of water, or another mechanism may be necessary to promote mixing through diffusive processes. When compared to well-mixed samples, these experiments demonstrate how the initial size and distribution of secondary phase particles is important for the evolution of a polymineralic rock into a fine-grained, well-mixed shear zone. We also notice that the olivine grains near the MgO inclusion have a grain size about half that of the olivine matrix further from the inclusion. Additionally, the olivine grains near the inclusion a different and weaker crystallographic preferred orientation (CPO) than in the rest of the olivine matrix indicating activation of the [001](100) slip system, rather than [100](010) in the matrix. These microstructural features are not observed when we deformed a single crystal of olivine in a polycrystalline olivine matrix under similar conditions, suggesting that the large second phase inclusion influences neighboring olivine grains by pinning them from growing and keeping them from rotating into orientations favorable for slip to occur.
